quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your project team has created comprehensive documentation for every deliverable, following detailed processes and contract negotiations. However, customers are unhappy because the software doesn't work as expected, and the team is too rigid to adapt to feedback. The contract states exactly what will be delivered, but market conditions have changed significantly.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: According to the Agile Manifesto, what should be your PRIMARY focus?

options.A: Following the contract and comprehensive documentation since they were agreed upon
options.B: Working software, customer collaboration, and responding to the changed conditions
options.C: Sticking to processes and tools to maintain consistency
options.D: Renegotiating the contract before making any changes

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Working software, customer collaboration, and responding to the changed conditions

trapSection.explanation: Options A, C, and D prioritize the LEFT side of the Agile values (documentation, processes, contracts) over the RIGHT side.

patternRecognition.patternRule: The Agile Manifesto values the items on the RIGHT more than the items on the LEFT. While the left items have value, the right items have MORE value.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: The Agile Manifesto is the foundation of all Agile approaches. Here's what PMI expects you to know:

rows.action: Deliver functioning products that customers can use
rows.examKeywords: working software, functional deliverable, usable product

rows.action: Prioritize people and communication over rigid processes
keyQuestions: Is the process helping or hindering?
rows.examKeywords: team collaboration, communication, people over process

rows.action: Deliver value frequently, from weeks to months
Welcome changing requirements, even late in development
keyQuestions: What does the customer need now?

rows.action: Business people and developers work together daily
keyQuestions: Are business and dev talking daily?
rows.examKeywords: daily collaboration, business alignment, stakeholder engagement

step.name: Give Trust & Support to Motivated People

rows.action: Build projects around motivated individuals, trust them
Most efficient communication is face-to-face conversation

step.name: Live by Working Software as Progress

rows.action: Working software is the primary measure of progress
rows.examKeywords: working product, measure progress, tangible results

rows.action: Maintain a constant, sustainable pace indefinitely
rows.examKeywords: sustainable pace, no overtime, steady velocity

coreFramework.additionalContent:
üí° The 4 Core Values

1. Individuals & interactions over processes & tools

2. Working software over comprehensive documentation

3. Customer collaboration over contract negotiation

4. Responding to change over following a plan

That is, while there is value in the items on the left, we value the items on the right MORE.

pmbokConnection.quote: The Agile Manifesto provides the foundation for all Agile approaches and methodologies

steps: G - Give trust to motivated people

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: The Agile Manifesto has 4 VALUES and 12 PRINCIPLES. Remember: the right side has MORE value than the left (but both have value).
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: When choosing between documentation vs working software, process vs people, contract vs collaboration, or plan vs change‚Äîchoose the LATTER.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Exam questions test whether you understand BALANCE. Agile doesn't mean NO documentation‚Äîit means LESS emphasis on documentation than on working software.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Foundation for all Agile approaches - Scrum, Kanban, XP, Lean

secondScenario.title: Apply the Agile Manifesto
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to a new situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your team is delivering working software every two weeks, but the customer wants detailed architectural documentation before each release. The team says this documentation slows them down and the customer rarely reads it. However, the customer insists it's in the contract.
secondScenario.question: What's the BEST Agile approach?

options.A: Create all documentation as specified in the contract
options.B: Collaborate with the customer to find documentation that adds value without slowing delivery
options.C: Refuse to create any documentation since Agile values working software
options.D: Create minimal documentation only after each release

quotes.text: The Agile Manifesto emphasizes that while there is value in the items on the left (processes, documentation, contracts, plans), we value the items on the right MORE (individuals, working software, collaboration, responding to change).
quotes.author: Agile Alliance

quotes.text: The exam loves to test whether you understand BALANCE. Agile doesn't mean no planning or no documentation‚Äîit means LESS emphasis on those things compared to working software and customer collaboration. Don't pick extreme answers.
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: Successful Agile teams don't eliminate documentation‚Äîthey create JUST ENOUGH documentation to be useful. They don't ignore contracts‚Äîthey collaborate with customers to evolve agreements. The Manifesto is about emphasis and priorities.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: When you see Agile questions, ask: 'Which value is at play here?' Is it about people vs process? Working software vs docs? Collaboration vs contract? Change vs plan? Then choose the RIGHT side of that value.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: Agile Base Camp
memoryPalace.intro: Anchor the Agile Manifesto with this vivid mountain climbing story. As you read, visualize each scene:

story.title: The Agile Expedition Begins
story.narrative: You're starting your climb at Agile Base Camp. Four key guideposts mark the way, each pointing RIGHT (the direction of more value).

scenes.description: At the first signpost, you see two climbers talking and laughing (INDIVIDUALS) on the RIGHT side. On the LEFT, you see empty tools and a dusty process manual. The climbers are making progress; the tools sit unused.

At the second signpost, on the RIGHT you see a functioning rope system carrying supplies up the mountain (WORKING). On the LEFT, you see stacks of paper documentation about how the rope SHOULD work, but nothing is moving.

At the third signpost, on the RIGHT you see climbers and guides working together, adjusting the route in real-time (COLLABORATION). On the LEFT, you see someone alone with a contract, refusing to deviate from the original plan despite changed weather.

At the fourth signpost, on the RIGHT you see climbers adapting their route around a new crevasse (RESPONDING TO CHANGE). On the LEFT, you see someone stubbornly following the old map into danger (FOLLOWING A PLAN).

Beyond the four signposts, you see 12 stepping stones leading up the mountain: 1) Satisfy customer 2) Welcome change 3) Deliver frequently 4) Work together daily 5) Trust motivated people 6) Face-to-face talk 7) Working software = progress 8) Sustainable pace 9) Technical excellence 10) Simplicity 11) Self-organizing teams 12) Reflect & adjust.

story.moral: The four values point RIGHT‚Äîtoward more value. The 12 principles are the stepping stones that guide your daily climb. Follow them to reach Agile mastery.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and visualize the four signposts. Can you recall what's on the RIGHT (more value) and LEFT (less value) of each?
